Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Railroads, Railroad Workers, and Geographies of Social Change

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will focus on the role of railroads and railroad workers during the Mexican Revolution (1910-1920) in order to systematically analyze the role of transportation in the production of space and democratic social change. Although the Mexican Revolution is usually thought of as a series of agrarian revolts, the railroad and railroad workers played an important and often decisive role at various stages of the Revolution. This project focuses on railroad workers and their working conditions in order to understand how transportation infrastructures are fundamental to social change. In so doing it will offer new insights into the process of national identity formation and make novel theoretical contributions to labor history, transportation geography, and critical social theory. An additional benefit of this study is the indexing of a variety of archival materials and the creation of original, historical GIS datasets that future scholars can build upon.

As a defining moment in the country's history, the Mexican Revolution of 1910 to 1920 continues to shape the politics and culture of Mexican society. Although the Revolution has been extensively documented, the role of the railroads, railroad workers and the use of rail infrastructure remain largely unexplored from an historical, as well as a geographical, perspective. This work blends theoretical concepts from political economy, actor-network theory and labor geographies and uses a mixed methods approach that combines archival research, prosopography and historical GIS to reconstruct the socio-spatial environments of railroad workers. By analyzing railroads and railroad workers as active agents in the Revolution this project aims to understand how a means of accumulation like the railroad became an instrument to achieve democratic social change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project has given the Co-PI (a graduate student) the opportunity to conduct extensive archival research and to form a professional network of researchers, archivists, curators and professors. The Co-PI has conducted research at the Archivo General de la Nación; Center for Railroad Research and Documentation; History Research Center, Universidad Iberoamericana-Campus Torreón; Intituto Mora; Mapoteca Manuel Orozco y Berra; Museo Ferrocarrilero de Aguascalientes; National Institute of Anthropology and History-DEH Tlalpan; and the National Newspaper Library at UNAM. Co-PI has collected archival documents relating to railroad labor, labor unions, the National Railroads of Mexico, the newspaper El Ferrocarrilero (1904-1906), the magazine Ferronales, as well as maps and blue prints of railroad infrastructure along the Ciudad Juárez, Chihuahua, Torreón, Zacatecas and Aguascalientes corridor.

 

This dissertation offers important theoretical contributions to labor history, transportation geography, critical social theory and Mexican historiography. My work will draw upon and extend the conceptual linkages between actor-network theory and Marxist theory. By drawing on critical paradigms that focus on social actors and transportation infrastructures, the study provides a systematic account of the role of transportation in the making of social change. In addition, the focus on railroad workers and their working conditions contributes the labor geographies that have been missing from historical and geographic accounts of the Revolution.

 

By emphasizing the importance of railroad infrastructures and railroad workers to the democratic and revolutionary heritage of Mexico, this project helps redefine contemporary interpretations of the Revolution beyond Mexican historiography. An additional benefit of this study is the indexing of a variety of archival materials and the creation of original datasets that future scholars can build upon. While GIS has become a prominent field in Latin American universities, HGIS is a recent development throughout the region. Therefore, combined with a popular subject such as the Mexican Revolution, this study has the potential to promote HGIS in Mexico as well as Latin America more generally. Furthermore, this project represents a conscious effort to advance critical approaches to transportation research, as well an opportunity to demonstrate the powerful intersection between social-technical systems and social change for modern labor movements.
